intro: Spiroloba unguis, commonly known as the clawed spirogyra, is a freshwater algae belonging to the order Zygnematales. It is characterized by its spiral-shaped chloroplasts, which are arranged in a distinctive helical pattern within the cell. The plant typically grows in still or slow-moving freshwater environments, such as ponds and ditches. Its reproductive structures include conjugation tubes that facilitate the exchange of genetic material between adjacent cells. Spiroloba unguis plays a vital role in aquatic ecosystems by contributing to primary production and serving as a food source for various aquatic organisms.
